doc.title: Sector Recipe - Healthy Bites Cyclical Delights
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Cyclical Delights_2025-09-01

passages.text: IMPORTANT RESEARCH DISCLOSURES AND ANALYST CERTIFICATIONS LOCATED IN APPENDIX 1. Deutsche Bank does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. Thus, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
We prefer Cyclicals over Defensives - except for Health Care.

The manufacturing recovery is cooking so slowly that it is hardly being noticed. It took full 3 years until manufacturing PMls in Europe moved back up above 50 last week. In the same week, US manufacturing PMls beat expectations by almost 4 points. We like underappreciated manufacturing sectors. However, we leave the biggest manufacturing sector, Industrials, on Neutral. As we highlighted in June, its subsector Defence looked too expensive. The sector lost around \(13\%\) since, but we continue to miss a short- term catalyst.

Banks remains among our most favoured sectors, despite its best 1y performance since the Global Financial Crisis. Since 2023, Banks continued to substantially beat earnings expectations. Apart from short- term pullbacks, e.g. due to French politics, we see no reason why the fundamentally strong picture for Banks should change.

We continue to be bullish on Construction due to its strong European focus with the potential to benefit from fiscal stimulus, particularly in German infrastructure. While the sector has outperformed by \(6\%\) since we turned O/W last year, it remains reasonably priced, and we expect further upside.

Our stance on Chemicals and Basic Resources remains constructive. While both sectors should benefit from the green shoots in manufacturing as outlined above, we acknowledge risks stemming from recent weak earnings and guidance revisions.

While we prefer cyclical over defensive sectors, we double upgraded Health Care from U/W to O/W last week. After posting the weakest return among all sectors in the past 12 months, improving news flow creates an interesting entry opportunity. Reduced tariff risks following the EU- US joint statement, coupled with an attractive valuation and strong expected EPS growth of \(7\%\) for FY25, should support the sector going forward. Sharp negative earnings revisions should already factor in the sector's strong USD exposure.

We remain neutral on Consumer sectors. However, missing out on a bottoming out in Luxury is potentially the biggest risk in our sector calls. Sentiment has stabilized and strong equity markets create consumer wealth. For now, we wait for more evidence of a prolonged recovery of the sector.

We add Telcosour list of underweights and remain cautious on Staples. Other defensive sectors have good (e.g. Utilities) or improving fundamentals, but lack the cyclicity to outperform. For European Tech, we see little upside due to a potential deceleration in earnings growth in H2 and the ongoing debate about monetization of AI investments. Within Tech, we prefer semis over services.
Banks were the best, Health Care the weakest performer. We still like Banks and we recently double-upgraded Health Care to overweight.
STOXX Europe 600 sector performance: 12m
The return of EZ manufacturing PMIs > 50 reinforces our preference for Cyclicals over Defensives. Health Care is the only defensive sector we are overweight.
Consumer Discretionary includes Automobiles and Parts, Consumer Products, Retail, Travel & Leisure and Media.
Basic Resources and Chemicals tend to outperform after manufacturing PMI crosses 50.
**Manufacturing PMI moving back above 50 Sector perf.* after PMI recovery (average)**

Sector3m6m12mSTOXX Europe 6001.2%3.1%19.3%Basic Resources8.7%18.3%38.4%Chemicals5.5%5.8%22.1%Construction4.6%8.0%21.7%Personal and Household Goods4.5%5.5%17.5%Autos3.9%5.9%22.6%Industrials3.3%8.2%25.8%Travel & Leisure2.4%7.3%19.9%Utilities2.0%3.7%16.5%Retail1.5%3.2%13.9%Real Estate1.5%6.5%25.2%Energy1.5%4.5%15.1%Food & Beverage1.4%2.9%9.1%Banks0.3%2.9%14.7%Technology0.1%5.1%36.1%Media-0.1%3.7%31.0%Telcos-0.1%-0.4%24.1%Health Care-0.5%-0.5%12.0%Financial Services-1.2%4.4%20.1%Insurance-1.7%-0.9%14.0%
*EZ manufacturing PMI crosses 50 and stays above 50 for the full period. Price return. Top and bottom 3 values highlighted. Source: Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank Research 08/28/2025
Deutsche Bank Research
We double upgraded HC to O/W following the EU- US joint statement. Less tariff risks, cheap valuation, strong EPS growth and cautious estimates offer attractive upside.

- We double upgraded the sector to O/W following the EU-US joint statement on tariffs, which applied a cap of \(15\%\) on tariffs on European pharmaceuticals. The deal seems to apply to all production taking place in the EU, hence mostly covering also UK and Swiss drug makers as most of their production is located in the EU. While uncertainty around international pricing remains, such deal significantly reduced uncertainty for Pharma companies in our view.- Valuation: The sector trades at a \(12\%\) discount to its 10-year average P/E and at the 3rd percentile versus its 10y P/E history.- Earnings: Consensus expects strong earnings growth of \(7\%\) versus \(0\%\) for the STOXX 600 in FY25. Earnings estimates have been cut by \(7\%\) ytd, more than discounting tariff risks.- FX: While Health Care has a high USD exposure, our year-end EUR/USD forecast of 1.20 seems to be more than adequately reflected in negative earnings revisions as well as weak price performance.
Valuations are close to a 10y low
FY EPS cut by \(7\%\) ytd..
...and the sector strongly underperformed
Source: Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank Research 08/28/2025
Banks have been rallying but are still not expensive.

- Valuations: Banks have started to re-rate significantly since the end of 2023. However, they are still not expensive, trading at the \(58^{\text{th}}\) percentile vs the last 10y and trade at a \(36\%\) discount vs the broader STOXX 600.- Beats: Banks saw aggregate beats of \(13\%\) during the Q2 earnings season, strongly above the STOXX 600 long-term average beat rate of \(4\%\) and even above their own average beat rate of \(11\%\) over the past 2 years. Furthermore, Banks saw the best upgrade-to-downgrade ratio to guidance during the Q2 earnings season.- Lending: Euro Area loans grew by \(2.5\%\) yoy in June, mainly led by an acceleration in corporate loan growth (2.7% yoy). Growth has been particularly strong among higher GDP countries (e.g., Greece, Portugal), while France and Germany remain below average. See here for more details.- Net interest income: Despite the ECB having cut rates by 175 bps since August of last year, NII is still holding up nicely. Longer-term rates are expected to remain elevated or even increase further on the back of the German fiscal stimulus. The combination of higher rates and a recovering European economy continues to present a very favourable environment for Banks.- Broader Financials: Since Q4-24, consensus has revised upwards FY 25 earnings estimates for Financials by \(4\%\) while expectations for the broad STOXX 600 have been cut by \(9\%\) . Revisions have been most positive among Banks and Insurance, while estimates in Financial Services have been revised down by low-single-digits. When it comes to valuations, Insurance is trading at all time high valuations. We expect Banks to outperform Insurance companies.
Valuations at a premium vs 10y average but not expensive
Source: Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank Research 08/28/2025
Strong beats, growing lending, strong NII and a steep yield curve should continue to support Banks.
Quarterly earnings beats
Loan growth rising from lowest level in 9y
Source: Margin Monitor; August 2025: go South
NII still at high levels while NPLs are down\*
\\*Aggregate value, \(\mathbb{N} = 35\)
Steeper yield curve supportive for Banks
Source: Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank Research 08/28/2025
High revenue exposure to Europe, beneficiary of the fiscal stimulus and of a potential ceasefire in Ukraine.

We turned overweight on Construction in September last year on the back of the sector's strong European focus, cheap valuation and solid earnings growth. Since then, Construction outperformed the wider STOXX 600 by \(6\%\) . Manufacturing PMIs in Europe continue to improve and the Ifo construction index keeps trending upwards. We expect Construction to benefit significantly from the improving manufacturing environment in Europe, thanks to almost \(50\%\) of revenue exposure to Europe. Construction should be among the key beneficiaries of the German fiscal stimulus, especially in infrastructure. While it remains highly uncertain whether a ceasefire can be reached in Ukraine, any positive news on a de- escalation should provide further tailwinds to the sector. Valuations meanwhile have increased thanks to strong price performance. Trading at a \(2\%\) premium vs its 10y average, the sector is still not expensive, in our view.
Source: Polymarket, Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank Research 08/28/2025
We remain constructive on Chemicals and Basic Resources. Manufacturing PMIs have crossed 50, earnings growth should recover in H2, and positioning is still weak.

- We remain O/W Basic Resources and Chemicals. While sentiment has been rather weak among the two sectors, more green shoots are emerging.- EZ Manufacturing PMIs have finally crossed the 50 threshold after being in contractionary territory for 3 years. As we have shown in slide 3, Basic Resources and Chemicals tend to outperform the most after manufacturing PMIs cross 50.- The sectors should also benefit from the German fiscal stimulus for infrastructure and climate. For Chemicals, a recovery in construction, which is a key end-market to the sector, would be particularly beneficial. Furthermore, a ceasefire in Ukraine, leading to lower energy prices, would also be supportive.- For Basic Resources, a regression analysis based on copper prices suggests 20% upside given the current copper level.- Positioning in Materials remains weak, with current positioning in the 27th percentile and among the weakest sectors. See here for more details.- Admittedly, earnings as well as guidance revisions have not been in the sectors' favour. However, consensus expects a strong recovery in the year-on-year growth rates in H2 vs H1. After Chemicals earnings declined by 33% yoy in H1, consensus expects H2 growth to turn positive at 6% yoy. H2 earnings growth in Basic Resources is expected to remain slightly negative year-over-year (-3%), but sequentially, earnings are expected to improve by 2% vs H1.
Note: yoy change, 3m moving average for Chemicals and Basic Resources price performance.
Source: Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank Research 08/28/2025
Although earnings are expected to improve from a low base in H2, consumer confidence is still low, providing little evidence for a recovery, yet.

- Earnings in the sector have likely toughed in H1 and consensus expects a strong improvement starting in H2, supported by easier comps.- FY 25 earnings estimates have been cut by \(21\%\) since Q4-24. In our view, the sector more than reflects the impact of tariffs and a weaker USD, also considering that Luxury companies have already undertook price increases (or plan to) in order to mitigate the impact of tariffs. According to our DB analysts, the \(15\%\) tariff on European imports is manageable. However, the \(39\%\) tariff on Switzerland remains an overhang to Swiss Luxury names.- In terms of valuations, the sector currently trades in line with its 10y average.- While sentiment on the sector has improved, risks remain. Growth in China and tourist spending remain weak, consumer confidence among major economies is still low and political risk in France has intensified again recently with the government likely to face a new confidence vote.- We are waiting for more proof of a sustainable recovery.
\\*3m moving average, last data point on China from June
Aggregate earnings based on current index members with semi-annual earnings in each semester since H1-19, N=30.
Note: Luxury P/E is market-cap weighted, using 12m fwd P/Es. Sample: LVMH, L'Oreal, Hermes, Richemont, Moncler, Kering. Source: Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank Research 08/28/2025
Valuations look stretched and earnings momentum is slowing. Focus on smaller caps instead of large caps.

- Industrials trended higher again this year, driven by positive sentiment around German fiscal spending and a broader manufacturing recovery. Eurozone manufacturing PMIs finally returned to expansionary territory in August (50.5) after ranging below 50 for 3 years.- Valuations in the sector have expanded further and have now reached the highest premium over the STOXX 600 since at least 2006.- Whilst sales growth for the sector is expected to remain solid over the coming quarters, consensus now expects earnings growth to decelerate significantly, putting downward pressure on margins and further upward pressure on valuations.- We still see some upside potential in smaller cap Industrials, which trade significantly cheaper than large caps and should benefit more from the German growth story thanks to their more domestic focus. Large cap Industrials look increasingly overvalued, and we remain cautious.
Valuation remains expensive
Exp. earnings growth is underwhelming
Avg P/E by size - SC Industrials cheap
Source: Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank Research 08/28/2025
Industrials valuations look less stretched ex Defence.
Industrials vs Defence P/E (12m fwd)
Industrials sub-sector weights
Defence contrib. to Industrial YTD return (pp)
Note: Defence basket includes BAE Systems, Safran, Leonardo, Hensoldt, Rheinmetall, Renk. Source: Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank Research 08/28/2025
Short- term cautious, but long- term investment case remains intact.

Hopes for a ceasefire in Ukraine have recently dampened enthusiasm on the sector. Valuations have moderated slightly from their June highs but remain elevated. That said, the sector is pricing in robust earnings growth of \(\sim 20\%\) p.a. for the coming years which justifies elevated valuations to some extent.

Recent market reactions suggest a high sensitivity to news on a Ukraine ceasefire. We believe that a potential ceasefire is a short- term risk, but the long- term drivers of defence spending remain intact. Less US commitment to fund European defence needs, new NATO targets involving European rearmament and ongoing tensions in the Middle East and Eastern Europe should provide sustained demand in the longer- term.
Short- term: We see limited near- term catalysts after the NATO summit has passed. Valuations appear stretched in the absence of immediate positive triggers.
Long- term: Underlying geopolitical risks and structural shifts towards higher defence spending remain compelling for long- term investors.

Earnings: Tech saw strong earnings growth in H1 (+20% yoy), however consensus now sees earnings growth decelerating to low single digits in H2 (+2% yoy). Furthermore, after exceeding the upper bound of their trend corridor for roughly 1.5 years, Tech EPS are now trending towards the lower end of the range. Tariffs: the joint statement between EU- US capped the tariff rate on semis to 15%. The direct impact on FY EPS for the sector should be therefore even lower than the ca. 1% hit we estimated based on a higher tariff rate of 25% (see here). Valuations: the sector trades at a 12% premium vs its 10% average P/E (12m fwd) and trades expensive given the current level of the 10% Bund yield, based on historical correlations. The sector is down by 1% ytd: valuations have expanded by 5% but earnings have been revised down by 6% - not a healthy mix. Thematic: worries about profitability of AI investments weigh on sentiment together with the Chinese government's pressure on local OEMs and chip markers to source domestically. Foreign semiconductor companies are expected to see declining sales in China over the next years, especially US players (see here).
EPS point to lower bound of trend corridor
Tech quarterly earnings growth (yoy)
Tech trades expensive relative to rates\*
Some factors are improving for Staples, but very slowly. We expect defensive sectors to underperform higher growth cyclical sectors.

- While some factors are improving for Staples, the change is very slow, and we expect Defensives to underperform higher-growth cyclicals.- Negative factors: Bund yields are expected to remain on elevated levels due to the strong fiscal easing in Germany, reducing the attractiveness of Staples. In addition, the sector should face one of the strongest EPS hits from tariffs due to its complex supply chains and additional tariff risk from Section 232 is not off the table. Wage growth in the EZ and UK is expected to decline further over the coming months, and consumer confidence among major economies remains weak. Consensus expects Staples FY earnings to decline slightly this year (-3%).- Improving factors: Earnings growth is expected to improve in H2 vs H1 (yoy), but FY earnings revisions have been cut by 10% since Q4-24. Valuations currently trade at a 15% discount vs their 10% average P/E (12m fwd) as Staples underperformed the broader market by 6% ytd.
\\*Market-cap weighted, using 12m fwd P/Es. Sample: Nestle, Unilever, BAT, Anheuser-Busch, Diageo.
Aggregate earnings based on current index members with semi-annual earnings in each semester since H1-19, N=42.
FY earnings cut by 8% ytd
Source: Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank Research 08/28/2025
Telcos had an impressive run and great earnings growth in H1. We expect momentum to fade.

Telcos has been among the best performing sectors this year. Earnings growth was very strong, but price momentum was even stronger.- Accordingly, valuations have been picking up and no longer look appealing, especially considering the significant expected slowdown in earnings growth in H2.- Although the sector looks generally healthy with still attractive FCF, we expect it to underperform the broader market over the coming months.- Longer- term, deregulation & consolidation are being considered a potential positive driver for the sector by our analysts.- See latest research from our Telco team here.
Telcos quarterly earnings growth (yoy)
Valuations at a \(9\%\) premium vs 10y avg
Free-cash-flow\* yield > avg but declining
Source: Bloomberg Finance LP, Deutsche Bank Research 08/28/2025
